sections.label: Urban/Wastewater virome
sections.query: (virome OR "viral metagenomics") AND (wastewater OR sewage OR "built environment" OR urban)

sections.label: Metagenomics methods
sections.query: metagenomics AND (benchmark* OR pipeline OR "quality control" OR assembly OR classification)

items.title: Metagenomic Surveillance of Blood-Fed Mosquitoes for Assessing Zoonotic Risk in Managed Animal Settings.
items.authors: Mukesh Thakur, Stanzin Dolker, Avijit Ghosh, Lenrik K Wangmo, Vinaya K Singh, Mehedi Hasan
items.journal: Vector borne and zoonotic diseases (Larchmont, N.Y.)
items.abstract_snippet: Vector-borne zoonotic diseases remain a major global public health concern, particularly at interfaces where humans, domestic animals, and wildlife interact closely. Conventional surveillance approaches often fail to detect early zoonotic spillover events, esp…

items.title: Beyond borders: plasmids drive a shared antibiotic resistome in European urban water systems.
items.authors: Wanli He, Zhuofeng Yu, Ziqi Wu, Asmus Kalckar Olesen, Jonas Stenløkke Madsen, Arnaud Dechesne
items.abstract_snippet: Urban wastewater systems (UWSs) act as reservoirs and conduits for the dissemination of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs), with plasmids playing a central role in their spread. Despite their significance, the diversity and persistence of plasmids in UWSs rema…

items.title: Bacteriophages in gut metagenomes: from analysis to application.
items.authors: Zakharevich Natalia, Strokach Aleksandra, Shitikov Egor, Klimina Ksenia
items.abstract_snippet: Bacteriophages constitute a major component of the human gut virome, playing very important roles in shaping of the structure and function of the gut microbiota. Moreover, bacteriophages interact with the human immune system, thereby influencing various diseas…

sections.label: Influenza evolution
sections.query: (influenza OR flu) AND (evolution OR "positive selection" OR "antigenic drift" OR clade)

items.title: Immune history confers antibody- and T cell-dependent cross-protection against highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 viruses.
items.authors: Pamela H Brigleb, Bridgett Sharp, Lauren Lazure, Brandi Livingston, Shelby Patrick, Victoria Meliopoulos
items.abstract_snippet: The outbreak of highly pathogenic avian H5 influenza (HPAI) clade 2.3.4.4b in cattle has spread across the United States. Mice with pre-existing immunity to H1N1 virus or with a live-attenuated influenza vaccine showed protection against a lethal bovine-derive…

sections.label: H5N1 / avian influenza
sections.query: H5N1 OR "highly pathogenic avian influenza" OR HPAI

items.title: Emerging trends and hotspots in Oseltamivir resistance: insights from a bibliometric investigation.
items.authors: Siming Zhai, Yuzhu Dou, Zhengjiu Cui, Bin Yuan
items.abstract_snippet: Influenza has long been a serious global public health problem, and the risk of drug resistance to Oseltamivir, as a first-line antiviral drug, cannot be ignored. Although some research findings have been published, a systematic review of current research on O…

items.title: Milk as a Transmission Vehicle for Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A (H5N1).
items.authors: Carrie L Byington, Lisa Stellwagen, Lars Bode, Mitra Hooshmand, Donald P Pizzo, Hana Russo
items.abstract_snippet: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) (H5N1 hereafter) is an emerging pathogen in mammals. The recent recognition of H5N1 in dairy cattle increases opportunities for human exposure and infection and may accelerate a trajectory toward sustained human-to-hu…
